childMarkdownRemark.html: The class context represents the serverless context object. The context object provides properties for sending HTTP requests using the built-in HTTP client and storing data locally, getting information in environment variables.

children.value: represents the serverless context object. The context object provides properties for sending HTTP requests using the built-in HTTP client and storing data locally, getting information in environment variables.

examples.highlighted: import Router from 'router'; const app = Router({ mergeParams: true }); mimikModule.exports = (context, request, response) => { global.context = context; app(request, response, (e) => { request.end(JSON.stringify({ code: e ? 400 : 404, message: e || 'Not Found' })); }); }; app.get('/', (request, response) => { response.end('Hello World!'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, context

The read-only property edge returns an edge object. The edge object provides functions that decrypt the encrypted messages that come in from the Node Discovery API. Also the edge object can make requests to the mimik Global Backend Services in order to create a private tunnel which is a Bearer Endpoint (BEP).

Member of the class, context

This read-only property info returns a info object. The info object contains general information about the container in which the given microservice is running.

Member of the class, context

The read-only property env object returns an env object. The env object has the environment variables that have been passed into the microservice container upon initialization.

Member of the class, context

The read-only property storage returns a storage object. The storage object contains methods for storing and retrieving key-value information and files using the edgeEngine Runtime's internal data storage mechanism.

Member of the class, context

The read-only property http returns an http object. The http object provides functions for working the http client that is built into the edgeEngine Runtime environment.
The class decryptNodesOption describes the configuration options for extracting sensitive information from clusters.

children.value: describes the  configuration options for extracting sensitive information from clusters.

Member of the class, decryptNodesOptions

Use this property to set the cluster type. The possible values are account, proximity or local.

Member of the class, decryptNodesOptions

Use this property to set the callback function that gets executed upon success of the decryption attempt.

BE ADVISED! The result passed into success callback function will be the encrypted data that was [MORE TO COME]

Member of the class, decryptNodesOptions

Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when an decryption attempt throws an error.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class edge provides functions that enable a node to receive information about the cluster and back-end tunneling information. Also, the edgeEngine Runtime provides a function, requestBep(requestBepOption) that creates a private tunnel, which is a Bearer Endpoint (BEP). All communication conducted by the edge class is done securely.

children.value: provides functions that enable a node to receive information about the cluster and back-end tunneling information. Also, the edgeEngine Runtime provides a function,
that creates a private tunnel, which is a Bearer Endpoint (BEP). All communication conducted by the

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of class, edge

The function decryptEncryptedNodesJson decrypts information received from the edgeEngine Service Mesh.
The configuration options is an object that describes the options for extracting information from a cluster within the edgeEngine Service Mesh.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/localDevices', (request, response) => { context.http.request(({ url: 'http://127.0.0.1:8083/mds/v1/nodes?clusters=linkLocal', success: function (r) { if (!request.authorization) { response.status = 403; response.end(JSON.stringify({ 'msg': 'missing bearer token' }, 2, null)); return; } const authorization = request.authorization.split(' '); if (authorization.length < 2) { response.status = 403; response.end(JSON.stringify({ 'msg': 'missing bearer token' }, 2, null)); return; } const token = authorization[1]; const nodes = JSON.parse(r.data); const data = JSON.stringify(nodes.data); context.edge.decryptEncryptedNodesJson({ type: 'local', data, token, success: function (result) { // success option response.end(JSON.stringify(JSON.parse(result.data), null, 2)); }, error: function (err) { response.end(err.message); } }); }, error: function (err) { response.end(err.message); } })); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, edge

The function requestBep(requestBepOption) requests a BEP tunnel from the edgeEngine Runtime If a BEP has not already been created, the function creates a new Bearer Endpoint (BEP). If a BEP has already been created, the function returns the existing BEP.
The BEP request configuration options for receiving a private communication tunnel.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/localDevices', (request, response) => { context.edge.requestBep({ success: (result) => { console.log(result.data); } }); // ... });

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class formRequestOption publishes a methods that define how to work with the method handleFormRequest() in order to handle the HTTP Form POST.

children.value: publishes a methods that define how to work with the method
in order to handle the HTTP Form POST.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of class, formRequestOption

The callback function that gets executed as each part in a multipart/form request is processed
The key of the form element.
The filename corresponding to the key if the form element is a file

examples.highlighted: formRequestOptions.found = (name, filename) => { const formToDo = null; if(filename) { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for a file - name : ${name}, filename: ${filename}`); //if it's a photo of a cat, don't process it if(filename.startsWith(name.toLowerCase()) == 'cat'){ formToDo = {action: 'skip'}; }else{ formToDo = {action: 'store', path: filename}; } } else { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for text - name : ${name}`); formToDo = {action: 'get'}; } return formToDo; };

The callback function that gets executed when the internal found()method identifies a text segment of multipart/form request
The key of the form element.
The value of the form element corresponding to the name.

examples.highlighted: formRequestOptions.get = (name, value) => { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for a text - name : ${name}, value: ${value}`) };

childMarkdownRemark.html: The todo action in response to the get execution

Member of class, formRequestOption

The callback function that gets executed when the internal found()method identifies a file in a multipart/form segment of multipart/form request
The stored file path of the form element
The stored file size of the form element

examples.highlighted: formRequestOptions.store = (filepath, byteStored) => { console.log(`Saved a file in a multipart/form-data request - path : ${path}, bytesSaved: ${bytesSaved}`) };

This object is returned from callback functions that defined that are defined in the formRequestOptions that is passed as a parameter in the method, request.handleFormRequest(formRequestOptions). The object formRequestToDo publishes a property action that indicates the action that is a required for the the method request.handleFormRequest() to handle the HTTP Form POST.

children.value:
This object is returned from callback functions that defined that are defined in the formRequestOptions that is passed as a parameter in the method, request.handleFormRequest(formRequestOptions).
The object formRequestToDo publishes a property
that indicates the action that is a required for the the method request.handleFormRequest() to handle the HTTP Form POST.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Member of class, formRequestToDo The possible return value of this read-only property are: abort aborts the entire form request. skip skips the current key of the form request. store handles the form request using the store function provided in formRequestOption. get handles the form request using the get function provided in formRequestOption.

examples.highlighted: const actionType = formRequestToDo.action
examples.raw: const actionType = formRequestToDo.action
examples.description: const actionType = formRequestToDo.action

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of class, formRequestToDo

This read-only property returns the path to the file that has been saved by default in the edgeEngine Runtime,

examples.highlighted: const filePath = formRequestToDo.path
examples.raw: const filePath = formRequestToDo.path
examples.description: const filePath = formRequestToDo.path

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class http describes the HTTP request client that is built into the edgeEngine Runtime environment. The http class publishes a method request that is used to implement an HTTP request from an edge microservice.

children.value: describes the  HTTP request client that is built into the edgeEngine Runtime environment. The
that is used to implement an HTTP request from an edge microservice.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, http.

This property is a function that takes the httpClientOptions and parses it as an instance of a HTTP client interface.

children.value: This property is a function that takes the httpClientOptions and parses it as an instance of a HTTP client interface.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The HTTP request configuration options for making requests within the edge microservice context.

examples.highlighted: app.post('/data', (request, response) => { context.http.request(({ type: 'POST', data: '{}', url: 'http://www.example.com/data', authorization: 'Bearer token123', success: (result) => { response.end(result.data); }, error: (err) => { console.log(err); } })); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: The HTTP request configuration options for making requests within the edge microservice context.

The edgeEngine Runtime has a built-in HTTP client that enables making requests to external targets running on the internet. The built in HTTP client is represented by the http object. The class httpClientOptions describes the HTTP request configuration options that the built-in HTTP client uses when executing requests within an edge microservice. The important thing to understand about the built-in HTTP client is that the only way to tell it how to make a request is by providing information about the intended request via the httpClientOptions. The httpClientOptions object is passed to the constructor of the http class, like so: context.http.request(httpClientOptions).

The important thing to understand about the built-in HTTP client is that the only way to tell it how to make a request is by providing information about the intended request via the

Result of the HTTP request to the callback function.

Member of the class, httpClientOptions.
The error of HTTP request to the callback function
The error of HTTP request to the callback function

Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to assign the HTTP method that the built-in HTTP client uses when making a request. For example, if you want the built-in HTTP client to make a GET request, assign the following, httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "GET". If you want to the HTTP client to make a POST request, assign the following: httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "POST"

. If you want to the HTTP client to make a POST request, assign the following:

examples.highlighted: // to make a GET request httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "GET" // to make a POST request httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "POST"

Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this this property to set the body of a request that is to be executed by the built-in HTTP client. Typically the data property is set when implementing a POST or PUT request.

property is set when implementing a

examples.raw: httpClientOptions.data = "All good things take time."

Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the target URL that the built-in HTTP client targets when making a request.

children.value: Use this property to set the target URL that the built-in HTTP client targets when making a request.

examples.highlighted: httpClientOptions.url = "https://api.example.com/movies"
examples.raw: httpClientOptions.url = "https://api.example.com/movies"

Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the HTTP authorization header that the built-in HTTP client uses when making a request.

children.value: Use this property to set the HTTP authorization header that the built-in HTTP client uses when making a request.

examples.highlighted: httpClientOptions.authorization = "Bearer mytoken123"
examples.raw: httpClientOptions.authorization = "Bearer mytoken123"

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when a request executed by the built-in HTTP client is successful.

children.value: Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when a request executed by the built-in HTTP client is successful.

Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when a request executed by the built-in http client throws an error.

childMarkdownRemark.html: This object represents the HTTP request parameter that is passed in to an HTTP method handler within a given microservice.

children.value: This object represents the HTTP request parameter that is passed in to an HTTP method handler within a given microservice.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns the URL of the request.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const callingURl = req.url // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns HTTP method of the request, such as GET, POST, DELETE, PUT, etc.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const method = req.method // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns the HTTP Authorization Header.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const authorization = req.authorization // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns the body of the POST or PUT request when the content-type of the request is application/json.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const mybody = req.body // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

The function handleFormRequest(formRequestOption) handles HTTP POST with a content type ‘multipart/form-data’. The function takes a formRequestOption object provided by the developer. The function handleFormRequest(formRequestOption) has internal behavior that executes when called from within an HTTP POST method handler. Developers can enhance this behavior by adding callback functions to the parameter formRequestOptions.
passes the callback function required by request.handleFormRequest() to handle the HTTP Form POST.

examples.highlighted: app.post('/form', (request, response) => { const formRequestOptions = {}; formRequestOptions.found = (name, filename) => { const formToDo = null; if(filename) { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for a file - name : ${name}, filename: ${filename}`); //if it's a photo of a cat, don't process it if(filename.startsWith(name.toLowerCase()) == 'cat'){ formToDo = {action: 'skip'}; }else{ formToDo = {action: 'store', path: filename}; } } else { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for text - name : ${name}`); formToDo = {action: 'get'}; } return formToDo; }; formRequestOptions.get = (name, value) => { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for a text - name : ${name}, value: ${value}`) }; formRequestOptions.store = (filepath, byteStored) => { console.log(`Saved a file in a multipart/form-data request - path : ${path}, bytesSaved: ${bytesSaved}`) }; req.handleFormRequest(formRequestOptions); response.end(); });

children.value: sets the BEP request configuration options for receiving a private communication tunnel. The options are callback functions for handling

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class response describes an HTTP response that is the result of an HTTP request made by HTTP client that's built in to the edgeEngine Runtime

children.value: describes an HTTP response that is the result of an HTTP request made by HTTP client that's built in to the edgeEngine Runtime

childMarkdownRemark.html: Member of class, response Returns the HTTP response code. The default is 200.
Inserts an a string as the body of the response .
The string that will be inserted into the body of the HTTP response.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { response.statusCode = 200; response.end('<h1>Hello World!</h1>'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of class, response

Inserts a mime file into the HTTP response.
The path of the file that response.writeMimeFile() returns in the response
The file type of the return file. The default is application/json

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { response.statusCode = 200; const filePath = '/home/usr/example.jpeg'; response.writeMimeFile(filepath, 'image/jpeg'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class storage facilitates saving and retrieving data from the internal storage mechanism within the edgeEngine Runtime.

children.value: facilitates saving and retrieving data from the internal storage mechanism within the edgeEngine Runtime.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function getItem(key) returns the data from the internal storage mechanism within the edgeEngine Runtime.
The key value to use to lookup data within internal storage

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { const value = context.storage.getItem('key'); response.end(value); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: the value associated to the key

Member of the class, storage

The function, setItem(key, value) stores data in internal storage as a key-value pair.
The key by which data will be stored
The value to store

examples.highlighted: app.post('/form', (request, response) => { const { name } = JSON.parse(request.body); context.storage.setItem('name', name); response.end('value stored successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function, eachItem iterates through internal storage and makes a callback for each record in the result.
The callback that handles eachItem object exposed during the iteration of query against internal storage.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { context.storage.eachItem((key, value) => { // do something.... }); response.end('done'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function removeItem(key) removes a data entry from internal storage according to the key.
The key in a key-value pair indicated the key-value to remove from internal storage

examples.highlighted: app.delete('/form', (request, response) => { context.storage.removeItem('name'); response.end('item remove successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function saveFile(fileName, base64EncodedString) saves a file to internal storage.
The name of the file. to save
The content of the file to save as a base64Encoded binary data.

examples.highlighted: app.post('/file', (request, response) => { const base64 = '..........'; const fileName = 'base64.jpeg'; context.storage.saveFile(fileName, base64); response.end('item save successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function deleteFile(fileName) deletes a file from internal storage.
The name of the file to delete.

examples.highlighted: app.delete('/file', (request, response) => { const fileName = 'base64.jpeg'; context.storage.deleteFile(fileName); response.end('item delete successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: Member of the class, storage
The key from the database for the item
The value in the database associate with the key.
The key from the database for the item
The value in the database associate with the key.

The class edge provides functions that enable a node to receive information about the cluster and back-end tunneling information. Also, the edgeEngine Runtime provides a function, requestBep(requestBepOption) that creates a private tunnel, which is a Bearer Endpoint (BEP). All communication conducted by the edge class is done securely.

children.value: provides functions that enable a node to receive information about the cluster and back-end tunneling information. Also, the edgeEngine Runtime provides a function,
that creates a private tunnel, which is a Bearer Endpoint (BEP). All communication conducted by the

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of class, edge

The function decryptEncryptedNodesJson decrypts information received from the edgeEngine Service Mesh.
The configuration options is an object that describes the options for extracting information from a cluster within the edgeEngine Service Mesh.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/localDevices', (request, response) => { context.http.request(({ url: 'http://127.0.0.1:8083/mds/v1/nodes?clusters=linkLocal', success: function (r) { if (!request.authorization) { response.status = 403; response.end(JSON.stringify({ 'msg': 'missing bearer token' }, 2, null)); return; } const authorization = request.authorization.split(' '); if (authorization.length < 2) { response.status = 403; response.end(JSON.stringify({ 'msg': 'missing bearer token' }, 2, null)); return; } const token = authorization[1]; const nodes = JSON.parse(r.data); const data = JSON.stringify(nodes.data); context.edge.decryptEncryptedNodesJson({ type: 'local', data, token, success: function (result) { // success option response.end(JSON.stringify(JSON.parse(result.data), null, 2)); }, error: function (err) { response.end(err.message); } }); }, error: function (err) { response.end(err.message); } })); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, edge

The function requestBep(requestBepOption) requests a BEP tunnel from the edgeEngine Runtime If a BEP has not already been created, the function creates a new Bearer Endpoint (BEP). If a BEP has already been created, the function returns the existing BEP.
The BEP request configuration options for receiving a private communication tunnel.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/localDevices', (request, response) => { context.edge.requestBep({ success: (result) => { console.log(result.data); } }); // ... });

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class http describes the HTTP request client that is built into the edgeEngine Runtime environment. The http class publishes a method request that is used to implement an HTTP request from an edge microservice.

children.value: describes the  HTTP request client that is built into the edgeEngine Runtime environment. The
that is used to implement an HTTP request from an edge microservice.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, http.

This property is a function that takes the httpClientOptions and parses it as an instance of a HTTP client interface.

children.value: This property is a function that takes the httpClientOptions and parses it as an instance of a HTTP client interface.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The HTTP request configuration options for making requests within the edge microservice context.

examples.highlighted: app.post('/data', (request, response) => { context.http.request(({ type: 'POST', data: '{}', url: 'http://www.example.com/data', authorization: 'Bearer token123', success: (result) => { response.end(result.data); }, error: (err) => { console.log(err); } })); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: The HTTP request configuration options for making requests within the edge microservice context.

This object is returned from callback functions that defined that are defined in the formRequestOptions that is passed as a parameter in the method, request.handleFormRequest(formRequestOptions). The object formRequestToDo publishes a property action that indicates the action that is a required for the the method request.handleFormRequest() to handle the HTTP Form POST.

children.value:
This object is returned from callback functions that defined that are defined in the formRequestOptions that is passed as a parameter in the method, request.handleFormRequest(formRequestOptions).
The object formRequestToDo publishes a property
that indicates the action that is a required for the the method request.handleFormRequest() to handle the HTTP Form POST.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Member of class, formRequestToDo The possible return value of this read-only property are: abort aborts the entire form request. skip skips the current key of the form request. store handles the form request using the store function provided in formRequestOption. get handles the form request using the get function provided in formRequestOption.

examples.highlighted: const actionType = formRequestToDo.action
examples.raw: const actionType = formRequestToDo.action
examples.description: const actionType = formRequestToDo.action

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of class, formRequestToDo

This read-only property returns the path to the file that has been saved by default in the edgeEngine Runtime,

examples.highlighted: const filePath = formRequestToDo.path
examples.raw: const filePath = formRequestToDo.path
examples.description: const filePath = formRequestToDo.path

childMarkdownRemark.html: The edgeEngine Runtime has a built-in HTTP client that enables making requests to external targets running on the internet. The built in HTTP client is represented by the http object. The class httpClientOptions describes the HTTP request configuration options that the built-in HTTP client uses when executing requests within an edge microservice. The important thing to understand about the built-in HTTP client is that the only way to tell it how to make a request is by providing information about the intended request via the httpClientOptions. The httpClientOptions object is passed to the constructor of the http class, like so: context.http.request(httpClientOptions).

children.value: The edgeEngine Runtime has a built-in HTTP client that enables making requests to external targets running on the internet. The built in HTTP client is represented by the

describes the HTTP request configuration options that the built-in HTTP client uses when executing requests within an edge microservice. The important thing to understand about the built-in HTTP client is that the only way to tell it how to make a request is by providing information about the intended request via the
object is passed to the constructor of the

childMarkdownRemark.html: Member of the class, httpClientOptions.
Result of the HTTP request to the callback function.
Result of the HTTP request to the callback function.
Member of the class, httpClientOptions.
The error of HTTP request to the callback function
The error of HTTP request to the callback function

Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to assign the HTTP method that the built-in HTTP client uses when making a request. For example, if you want the built-in HTTP client to make a GET request, assign the following, httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "GET". If you want to the HTTP client to make a POST request, assign the following: httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "POST"

children.value: Use this property to assign the HTTP method that the built-in HTTP client uses when making a request. For example, if you want the built-in HTTP client to make a GET request, assign the following,
. If you want to the HTTP client to make a POST request, assign the following:

examples.highlighted: // to make a GET request httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "GET" // to make a POST request httpClientOptions.httpMethod = "POST"

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this this property to set the body of a request that is to be executed by the built-in HTTP client. Typically the data property is set when implementing a POST or PUT request.

property is set when implementing a

examples.highlighted: httpClientOptions.data = "All good things take time."
examples.raw: httpClientOptions.data = "All good things take time."

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the target URL that the built-in HTTP client targets when making a request.

children.value: Use this property to set the target URL that the built-in HTTP client targets when making a request.

examples.highlighted: httpClientOptions.url = "https://api.example.com/movies"
examples.raw: httpClientOptions.url = "https://api.example.com/movies"

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the HTTP authorization header that the built-in HTTP client uses when making a request.

children.value: Use this property to set the HTTP authorization header that the built-in HTTP client uses when making a request.

examples.highlighted: httpClientOptions.authorization = "Bearer mytoken123"
examples.raw: httpClientOptions.authorization = "Bearer mytoken123"

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when a request executed by the built-in HTTP client is successful.

children.value: Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when a request executed by the built-in HTTP client is successful.

examples.highlighted: httpClientOptions.success = (result) => {console.log(`The request was successful. The result is: ${result}`)};
examples.raw: httpClientOptions.success = (result) => {console.log(`The request was successful. The result is: ${result}`)};

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, httpClientOptions.

Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when a request executed by the built-in http client throws an error.

children.value: Use this property to set the callback function that gets invoked when a request executed by the built-in http client throws an error.

examples.highlighted: httpClientOptions.error = (error) => {console.error(`The request was has an error. The error is: ${error}`)};
examples.raw: httpClientOptions.error = (error) => {console.error(`The request was has an error. The error is: ${error}`)};

childMarkdownRemark.html: This object represents the HTTP request parameter that is passed in to an HTTP method handler within a given microservice.

children.value: This object represents the HTTP request parameter that is passed in to an HTTP method handler within a given microservice.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns the URL of the request.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const callingURl = req.url // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns HTTP method of the request, such as GET, POST, DELETE, PUT, etc.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const method = req.method // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns the HTTP Authorization Header.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const authorization = req.authorization // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

Returns the body of the POST or PUT request when the content-type of the request is application/json.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/photos', (req, res) => { const mybody = req.body // ... more code });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, request

The function handleFormRequest(formRequestOption) handles HTTP POST with a content type ‘multipart/form-data’. The function takes a formRequestOption object provided by the developer. The function handleFormRequest(formRequestOption) has internal behavior that executes when called from within an HTTP POST method handler. Developers can enhance this behavior by adding callback functions to the parameter formRequestOptions.
passes the callback function required by request.handleFormRequest() to handle the HTTP Form POST.

examples.highlighted: app.post('/form', (request, response) => { const formRequestOptions = {}; formRequestOptions.found = (name, filename) => { const formToDo = null; if(filename) { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for a file - name : ${name}, filename: ${filename}`); //if it's a photo of a cat, don't process it if(filename.startsWith(name.toLowerCase()) == 'cat'){ formToDo = {action: 'skip'}; }else{ formToDo = {action: 'store', path: filename}; } } else { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for text - name : ${name}`); formToDo = {action: 'get'}; } return formToDo; }; formRequestOptions.get = (name, value) => { console.log(`Received a multipart/form-data for a text - name : ${name}, value: ${value}`) }; formRequestOptions.store = (filepath, byteStored) => { console.log(`Saved a file in a multipart/form-data request - path : ${path}, bytesSaved: ${bytesSaved}`) }; req.handleFormRequest(formRequestOptions); response.end(); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class response describes an HTTP response that is the result of an HTTP request made by HTTP client that's built in to the edgeEngine Runtime

children.value: describes an HTTP response that is the result of an HTTP request made by HTTP client that's built in to the edgeEngine Runtime

childMarkdownRemark.html: Member of class, response Returns the HTTP response code. The default is 200.
Inserts an a string as the body of the response .
The string that will be inserted into the body of the HTTP response.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { response.statusCode = 200; response.end('<h1>Hello World!</h1>'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of class, response

Inserts a mime file into the HTTP response.
The path of the file that response.writeMimeFile() returns in the response
The file type of the return file. The default is application/json

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { response.statusCode = 200; const filePath = '/home/usr/example.jpeg'; response.writeMimeFile(filepath, 'image/jpeg'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: The class storage facilitates saving and retrieving data from the internal storage mechanism within the edgeEngine Runtime.

children.value: facilitates saving and retrieving data from the internal storage mechanism within the edgeEngine Runtime.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function getItem(key) returns the data from the internal storage mechanism within the edgeEngine Runtime.
The key value to use to lookup data within internal storage

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { const value = context.storage.getItem('key'); response.end(value); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: the value associated to the key

Member of the class, storage

The function, setItem(key, value) stores data in internal storage as a key-value pair.
The key by which data will be stored
The value to store

examples.highlighted: app.post('/form', (request, response) => { const { name } = JSON.parse(request.body); context.storage.setItem('name', name); response.end('value stored successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function, eachItem iterates through internal storage and makes a callback for each record in the result.
The callback that handles eachItem object exposed during the iteration of query against internal storage.

examples.highlighted: app.get('/', (request, response) => { context.storage.eachItem((key, value) => { // do something.... }); response.end('done'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function removeItem(key) removes a data entry from internal storage according to the key.
The key in a key-value pair indicated the key-value to remove from internal storage

examples.highlighted: app.delete('/form', (request, response) => { context.storage.removeItem('name'); response.end('item remove successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function saveFile(fileName, base64EncodedString) saves a file to internal storage.
The name of the file. to save
The content of the file to save as a base64Encoded binary data.

examples.highlighted: app.post('/file', (request, response) => { const base64 = '..........'; const fileName = 'base64.jpeg'; context.storage.saveFile(fileName, base64); response.end('item save successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Member of the class, storage

The function deleteFile(fileName) deletes a file from internal storage.
The name of the file to delete.

examples.highlighted: app.delete('/file', (request, response) => { const fileName = 'base64.jpeg'; context.storage.deleteFile(fileName); response.end('item delete successfully.'); });

childMarkdownRemark.html: Member of the class, storage
The key from the database for the item
The value in the database associate with the key.
The key from the database for the item
The value in the database associate with the key.
